data.text: @_bonewizard I will miss him and I hope he gets back soon.
RT @alfranken: Sinema says she’s always been the same ideologically. Strange. She was a Green in the AZ state leg. Don’t remember them figh…

RT @MsPackyetti: Kyrsten Sinema switched to being an independent because she was never really a Dem and couldn’t survive an Arizona Primary…
@kcpenny @andyhartzler Karens gotta Karen
RT @Tim_Tweeted: Vicky Hartzler’s gay nephew Andrew posted about his aunt crying over gay marriage on the House floor https://t.co/Kxwt4DLE…

@IdiotTracker 1) We aren't really talking about the same procedures.  Anesthesia itself presents significant physiologic risks, and you aren't really dealing with procedures that take hours and hours.
2) We also do emergent cases blind.  Elective cases have a different risk/benefit ratio.
@IdiotTracker So when I ask for preop "clearance," it's because my anesthesiologist gestalt says that I need more information to do a case safely.

It's weird how willing people are to be super cavalier about risks that *other people* should be willing to take.

Yes this is an anesthesia tweet.
@apskovsen @JRamaMD No that's laparoscopic
@AlanHawxbyMD #accurate
Not an ASA 2 https://t.co/Uz65qhvi7Y
@Jasonskelly6 @painless42 Same with continuous oxygen I mean what
People being sarcastic in Spanish just hits different.
@ParkerEaton That is correct.  And occasionally I wonder if I am on ME turf.
@CallTheBall22 Ha true
@D_PaulAngel That would be helpful yes
@rhinedog55 Basically that you have one or more low-level health conditions (high blood pressure, asthma, etc), but they are under control and not causing you any big issues.
@painless42 I've never seen an ASC that wouldn't do 3s, but not a factor in this case.
I just got a "preop clearance" that said, in its entirety, "Proceed with surgery." https://t.co/znC5vQBreS
@Julietilsen A lot of people now kinda have to live wherever they can afford to live.
@Exploratorylap You should read my tweet again.
@MHalloner What a fascinating assertion.
@MHalloner @drafoxter Can you prove improved patient outcome?
ASA classification is not supposed to be the same as the number of failed organ systems.
@MHalloner @drafoxter Gas released into the atmosphere is pretty much directly correlated with procedure time.
@jeffreyswisher It is here and I do not understand it
@MHalloner @drafoxter Oh my sweet summer child.
@mrultiva Okay but THAT'S THE WRONG FEELING
@lmhuber1982 Okay, I did three robotic surgeries yesterday.  Feel free to enlighten me.
@MHalloner @drafoxter I assure you that a procedure that usually takes 15 minutes and now takes 4 hours does indeed increase anesthetic gas.
@MHalloner Gonna have to show that for each of these surgeries, chief.
Okay honest question:  why do you, a male anesthesiologist over the age of 50, insist on calling all patients, up to and including people SITTING IN JESUS'S WAITING ROOM, ASA 2s??
What in the absolute shit is this https://t.co/b009q7TJ21
@NativeCACV @SafePartum @SOAPHQ @ruthi_landau @LimGrapes @Ron_George @emilysharpe @OBsleepmerchant I cannot be the only one who just bought a bunch of spare keys and attached them to all my badges.
@MichaelKWest1 They do not, although I am 50/50 that a couple of my partners could be cyborgs.

@AlanHawxbyMD The thing that actually broke me on that song was hearing it 8-9 times on the radio/pandora in a day, shutting it all off, and then coming home to have my mother-in-law singing it in my kitchen.
@AlanHawxbyMD https://t.co/DAAdMGBHP7
@JRamaMD This. Is. Genius.
RT @acweyand: Almost every single type of pediatric cancer.
@DocWithBowtie @Gabby_Brauner27 Poor kidneys
@JenniferZahn5 The good thing is that you can pick any Ed Sheeran song, and while you may not be exactly right, you will also not be totally wrong.
@m_pollack I absolutely will not even think of the name
@frakinskinjob @Crnainthecity Glad it went well for you!
@DrFlyover So, so close
@epcorley1 Although your anesthesia bill is a lot higher if robotic takes a lot longer.
@SixOnTheOther @DrFlyover Although it remains a case in point.
@SixOnTheOther @DrFlyover Yup
@Modwickey @kristopheRogers That's gross.
@epcorley1 I might be wrong but I don't think robotic surgery pays better.
@Crnainthecity Wut
I know I'm old-fashioned, but maybe not EVERY surgery needs to be done with a robot.
@TgardnerH Ugh, you're right.
@AmolUtrankar I think it's smart, if only to know what you are agreeing to.  However, the larger the group, the less likely they will be willing to make changes.

This is the weirdest gatekeeping ever.

"If you care about Americans being sent to Russian penal colonies so much then what were their free throw percentages??  #checkmate" https://t.co/KeyEzNNH8y
@magicalsleeper @logicalkitty @chalommm @ZackBornstein Oh my god you must be exhausting.
@Jasonskelly6 @savayvay17 Yup

@Jasonskelly6 @GratefulNole But usually it's the normal stuff... you'll get fired if you have a long turn over (no), they'll get mad if you need an art line or whatever (no), you can't cancel cases (my personal best is 3 in a day), we cut all kinds of corners for speed or surgeon happiness (also no)...

@Jasonskelly6 @GratefulNole Oh god...one time they told me that my group made everyone write the group a $100k check when we had a rough quarter and insisted that I was wrong when I told them that never happened.  Like I think I would recall.

@Jasonskelly6 @savayvay17 Agree with all of these, also how are cases/scheduled assigned, is the unit value socialized (beware if not), can you generally get the vacation that you want, how is holiday coverage arranged.
@TradeTexasBig No, PP married to an academic
@savayvay17 @drtedritchie I mean it depends on your priorities.  I chose to have a million children instead of a Porche. 🤷‍♀️
@PaulieMD1260 Oh god one of my kids was obsessed with Imagine Dragons for a while.

What's the one song that makes you have a visceral reaction of horror and disgust?

Mine's that Ed Sheeran song.  You know which one.
Oooooh love this! https://t.co/czj2M2pNhI
@GratefulNole OMG, a ton of my friends (who I love) are academic, and many of them spend a shocking amount of time saying bonkers things to me about PP.
@tonymompy @DruvBhagavan It's nice to have a ton of people around and a lot of fancy toys.  It's also nice to have the confidence to fly with less of a net.
@Scottgolf63 I can't tell you how hard I feel this

@kristopheRogers No, I actually haven't.  Absolutely ask for details about the path to partnership and the % of partnership track people who become partner.  If the path is very long (>3 years) or less than about 95% become partner, be careful.
@TradeTexasBig You can, although this also varies widely, and the large gap between academics and PP has closed a lot since the 90s.
@adamwolach Totally depends on your practice.  Although I work at a lot of hospitals, I nearly never go to more than one in a day.
@galliummd @DrCasteelEM I mean, great, but US is a fantastic tool and a good skill to have.
RT @DrCasteelEM: Med students and residents: becoming comfortable and skilled at placing ultrasound guides peripheral IVs is one of the mos…
@MortytheRN @DrLongissimus Yaaaassssss
@Jensgotthis1 Yes it varies greatly between my hospitals.

@drtedritchie I had a couple of insurance lobbyists tell people that I have two Lamborghinis, so the Porsche is kind of a downgrade.

(I have neither a Porsche nor a Lamborghini)
@Jensgotthis1 Hahahaha I'm afraid that it's not super posh most of the time, but I WILL say that my academic husband is VERY jealous that all of my hospitals give me free food.
@DruvBhagavan Often resources -- both equipment and personnel -- are more sparse in PP.  This has pluses and minuses. 5/

@DruvBhagavan I have found that the idea that people are somehow not as sick in PP to be absolute nonsense, although that would be true in some specific outpatient practices.  We do tend to see a little less of the more "exotic" chronic pathologies. 4/

@DruvBhagavan While, again, practices vary, I have not seen the wild production pressure that I hear academic people talk about being rampant in PP, and I would say that it's pretty similar between my academic husband and his colleague and my practice. 3/

@DruvBhagavan Obviously academic folk as a group spend more time on research that PP people, although there are some of us in PP who do quite a lot of "scholarly activity" and some academics who don't do a ton. 2/

@DruvBhagavan I think that this is a little bit of a tough question to answer, since there is a very wide range in practice among both academic and private practices, but broadly I would say that there is less difference than is generally assumed. 1/
@loumaycam Also all people in medicine like to shit talk all other people in medicine.
@Scottgolf63 That’s impossible, private practice docs don’t do Level 1 trauma!  /s
@loumaycam My opinion?  Because most academic anesthesiologists have never been in private practice (or have extremely limited exposure) so don’t really have a good perspective.

Okay, anesthesiology residents — there is A LOT of myths about private practice anesthesia.  AMA!

Feel free to DM me if you want to remain anonymous.

@shdwstar Oooh

Sure why not have badge access to hospital entrances disabled at night.  Not like anyone ever needs us to get there in a hurry.

I hope you're happy now.

@EruditeElf Well I mean there’s 23 million locals so that doesn’t totally narrow it down in this case.

tweets.text:
Michael Bosco, the man we know and love, is taking a break from Twitter (timeline tbd) bc of the general toxicity of the environment. 

Do not worry, however, he is doing okay. 

I will not be taking any questions.
Sinema says she’s always been the same ideologically. Strange. She was a Green in the AZ state leg. Don’t remember them fighting for tax breaks for the wealthy.
Kyrsten Sinema switching to an Independent days after Democrats won the GA runoff is all you need to know about Kyrsten Sinema.

Kyrsten Sinema switched to being an independent because she was never really a Dem and couldn’t survive an Arizona Primary. She also waited until after the GA runoffs so the Dems can’t celebrate 51 anymore. None of this is surprising but it is confirmation that she is the worst.
@andyhartzler Seriously, though, why is she crying?
Vicky Hartzler’s gay nephew Andrew posted about his aunt crying over gay marriage on the House floor https://t.co/GECcKze5LN https://t.co/Kxwt4DLEnF

@fuzzymittens Context: in the ED we do a lot of these procedures blind, always assuming there could be trouble but dealing with it as we find it. Maybe it'd be a disaster to import that philosophy to non-emergent cases. Or maybe it'd be fine & we could save a lot of time and money and delays.
@fuzzymittens Would love to see the RCT on per-op-clearence lives saved via medical optimization vs lives lost by delaying needed surgeries and wasting a huge amount of time and resources.
@JRamaMD @fuzzymittens Agree.. but that would pretty much amount to intubating with a McGrath video laryngoscope 🤷‍♂️
@fuzzymittens ORTHO wants to schedule his THA for Saturday at 0700.
@fuzzymittens @painless42 I’ve seen this too and it’s maddening.  If you’re on Xarelto, you’re not a 2.  Change my mind.
@fuzzymittens Also, aren't we your patients until we become the Medical Examiner's patient?
@fuzzymittens I don't know if this is better or worse than "maintain normal blood pressure and oxygenation." 🤨
@fuzzymittens I'm guessing you need *slightly* more information than that to do your job?
@fuzzymittens Asa 2 means?
@fuzzymittens Because their ASC won’t permit operating on ASA 3’s?

@fuzzymittens Most lap cases are at the very least non-inferior on the robot. 
A lot of surgeons aren’t trained in advanced laparoscopy/thorascopy. So for them, it’s not robot vs lap. It’s robot vs open.
@fuzzymittens I'm just a somewhat I formed pt,not a MD there sport,but I'd bet dollars to donuts it improves pt outcomes/recovery in most instances.
@fuzzymittens @drafoxter Perhaps a bit of hyperbole on your part, but if In fact some do require more time bot vs standard,isn't improved pt outcome the gold standard in surgical treatment?
@fuzzymittens @drafoxter Gas needed for a 4hr procedure vs 15min? Of course. Increased evap as said? Negligible amt I'd imagine, and WHY would a 15min procedure take 4 hrs w/robot assist?
@fuzzymittens This is a thing?? (Asked by a 60+ year old male anesthesiologist)
@fuzzymittens ASA is more, like you know, a feeling?
@fuzzymittens Robotic assisted surgery is a very good thing.
@drafoxter @fuzzymittens Less med waste produced,no significant increase in gas evap,and yes higher procedure cost. Cadillacs cost more than mazdas.
@fuzzymittens Idk doc. If it reduces insult to body,improves post op infect rates and reduces post op pain....why not?

I thought coming home after finally finishing the USMLE step series would be such a victorious moment. Instead I’m replaying the moment where my examiner told me he “did not like my attitude” and proceeded to turn off my computer MID-EXAM.
@SafePartum @SOAPHQ @ruthi_landau @LimGrapes @fuzzymittens @Ron_George @emilysharpe @OBsleepmerchant Airtag for the key! I feel seen.
@fuzzymittens Do they do anesthesia with a robot?
@AlanHawxbyMD https://t.co/DAAdMGBHP7

@fuzzymittens I just learned it on guitar.  
Stop by, I'll sing it at work.
@fuzzymittens I suggest you insist on robotic intubation every time the da Vinci is used.
Almost every single type of pediatric cancer. https://t.co/v0kEFloqyg

How to mystify the youths, according to @Gabby_Brauner27.

(This is not actually to mock, just a reflection of how rounds have evolved. Also the bar is not censoring anything, it’s just another number I wrote down that wasn’t part of the fishbone thing.) https://t.co/WNAAibQX1r
@fuzzymittens I still have no idea which Sheeran song it is
@fuzzymittens Which one?

@Crnainthecity @fuzzymittens I had DaVinci liver resection done, highly recommend it from the recovery angle. I also have stage 4 emphysema which means probable complications with recovery. I was off the vent in just under 12 hrs, home in a week, on the exercise bike 3 wks later. 🙌
@fuzzymittens This has to be about a robotic umbilical hernia repair? Amirite?
@epcorley1 I might be wrong but I don't think robotic surgery pays better.
@SixOnTheOther @DrFlyover Yup
@DrFlyover @fuzzymittens For tonsils?
@kristopheRogers @fuzzymittens I have. I am a CRNA but in an old group I was in suddenly the partner track disappeared when several MDs were a year away.
@fuzzymittens It does if you want to impress your patient and charge for “robotic surgery “
@fuzzymittens Lol just having this discussion with the HBV team. They are talking about doing robotic liver transplants. 🤪. Thoughts ?!
@fuzzymittens The logic is horrifying but straightforward: they simply cannot imagine caring about the humanity of a black woman outside of her athletic achievements.
@fuzzymittens Having a lawyer review your contract: worthwhile or waste of time/$?
The people who claim to care so much about Brittney Griner can't even name what team she was on without googling it.
@logicalkitty @chalommm @ZackBornstein Ah yes, the good ol “manipulate other people for our benefit” tactic. teach me!
@fuzzymittens @savayvay17 Socialized like “blended units”?

@Jasonskelly6 @GratefulNole Oh god...one time they told me that my group made everyone write the group a $100k check when we had a rough quarter and insisted that I was wrong when I told them that never happened.  Like I think I would recall.
@fuzzymittens @GratefulNole What do they say?

@savayvay17 @fuzzymittens Typical day start/stop time, payor mix, supervision ratios, partnership track details, support staff, general morale (does the staff get along), would you pick a different job knowing what you know now? Get noncompete language out of a contract and get malpractice tail coverage.
@fuzzymittens you are an academic ?
@fuzzymittens @drtedritchie What if I want a Porsche? Could I afford one in private practice and still be able to sleep well at night?
@fuzzymittens Imagine dragons “thunder” or “believer”

Here’s our first ever gift guide for the #OBAnes in your life (or anyone who wants to be comfy while on call)! Leave your on-call essentials in the comments to be included in our next list! @SOAPHQ @ruthi_landau @LimGrapes @fuzzymittens @Ron_George @emilysharpe @OBsleepmerchant https://t.co/BHpvtZE1Kl

@fuzzymittens I was in private practice for 15 years and made a mid career switch to academia for a change of pace. It was always hilarious to me to hear attendings who had never left academia talk about what it was like in private practice. With me sitting right there!
@fuzzymittens @DruvBhagavan Hey, what are the pluses and minuses of this?
@fuzzymittens I wish we didn’t have to some nights

@fuzzymittens Really interested in hearing more. Planning on PP pain but a lot of my co-residents are concerned about PP groups dangling “partnership” and never actually delivering. Have you heard of this happening frequently?
@fuzzymittens Can u make more money
@fuzzymittens Do you have to go to multiple hospitals in a day?

@DrCasteelEM Ultrasound guided? Back in the old days I could draw blood/start IVs in the most difficult patients with nothing to guide me. I am still, over 30 years later, the go-to at our office for difficult blood draws. Once drew blood from that vein on your thenar eminence.

Med students and residents: becoming comfortable and skilled at placing ultrasound guides peripheral IVs is one of the most empowering things you can do in the acute care setting. You are NOT above placing them, get good at them. You’ll be a better proceduralist bc of it.
@fuzzymittens Of the number of hospitals I have been fortunate to dine at that is either a well earned perk or not so much
@fuzzymittens Is it true that every one of u drives a Porsche?

@DruvBhagavan I have found that the idea that people are somehow not as sick in PP to be absolute nonsense, although that would be true in some specific outpatient practices.  We do tend to see a little less of the more "exotic" chronic pathologies. 4/

@DruvBhagavan While, again, practices vary, I have not seen the wild production pressure that I hear academic people talk about being rampant in PP, and I would say that it's pretty similar between my academic husband and his colleague and my practice. 3/

@DruvBhagavan Obviously academic folk as a group spend more time on research that PP people, although there are some of us in PP who do quite a lot of "scholarly activity" and some academics who don't do a ton. 2/

@DruvBhagavan I think that this is a little bit of a tough question to answer, since there is a very wide range in practice among both academic and private practices, but broadly I would say that there is less difference than is generally assumed. 1/

@fuzzymittens Not a resident (and I don't think I even know enough to have internalized any myths, haha), but I'm curious as to the differences between private practice anesthesia and practice in larger academic/community centers, more generally. Does it differ substantially?
@loumaycam My opinion?  Because most academic anesthesiologists have never been in private practice (or have extremely limited exposure) so don’t really have a good perspective.
@fuzzymittens What's the myth? Curious as I have been a private practice anesthesiologist in a Level 1 Trauma Hospital with surgery, medicine and OB residencies for 23 years.
@fuzzymittens ok i am not an anesthesia resident but why is private practice seen so negatively?

Yesterday a group of white, male academics disinvited me from their conference after I asked for equitable treatment as the other invited keynote speakers, who also happened to be white and male.
A 🧵 on sexism and discrimination in academia:
/1
What is wrong with these people https://t.co/pxWKxjF23P

My office has started Ubering our clients to places they need to be to do things like see their kids, get public benefits, get to their appointments, and connect them with material needs. So far the total cost has been less than $1500 in a total of 6 months. 1/

@fuzzymittens If you spray air duster into the top of the door it will pop open. The rapid temperature change triggers the sensor, and if that fails the other sensor for c02 triggers, causing it to open. Every system has a flaw.
@heatherh1093 @fuzzymittens Seconded. And so cheap! You could eat like a king at the finest restaurant and still have change from $20. (Only a slight exaggeration)

Former D.C. Officer Michael Fanone says members of his own department taunted him at congressional award ceremony today, calling him a "piece of s---." He has said he has been ostracized for being outspoken about the Capitol riot and those who play down the violence that day.

I’m not too concerned that Raphael Warnock will maintain his seat. I’m overly concerned that almost 50% of the population of GA voted for a guy who has no business running and can barely string a competent sentence together. #GArunoff
@fuzzymittens I am a bit curious now as to what “embarrassingly ill-advised” means in your world.
@fuzzymittens What’s your list
@fuzzymittens Always go where the locals go.

I just saw a video of a white guy who was like, "what happened if you gave it your all for one year, in your job, in your workouts, and in your life. How would that change your life?!" And I was like, "people can't even get children's Tylenol right now"
@fuzzymittens Let me know before you go. I have lists…
